review_title: If you're young ambitious and looking for career advancement don't work here.
job_title: Technical Support Engineer in Toronto, ON
pros: Decent salary (without the ability to ever get a real raise) with yearly cost of living increase. Looks good on a resume. The kind of place you work at for 2 years then move along, or become a lifer.
cons: No room to build new skills. Unsupportive middle managers. Project managers assigned to teams to make sweeping changes without listening to the people who actually do the work. I encountered uncomfortable comments about race and sexuality during my time here. UHN is riddled with middle managers who serve little to no purpose. People in positions to manage departments they dont understand or have backgrounds in. No room to advance your career. They hire externally for jobs far more suited for internal candidates who wish to advance. Being ambitious only means you will thanklessly tasked with doing all the work, with diminishing support. Half the people are generally hard working helpful and want to advance the programs and experience for the patients. The other half are "lifers" who do the bare minimum. If you understand the Peter principle, youll get the idea. Many departments managed by people that would never be able to advance further with no to desire to. Micromanagement of the employees who actually do the work without respect for their opinions. UHN is all about donations and research funding while patient care is run on shoe string budgets. The CEO and top people lied about patient and staff safety throughout the pandemic.

job_title: IT Technical Analyst in Toronto, ON
pros:
- Good balance in life vs. work environment surrounded by the smartest minds you'll find in Science.
- Amazing location (TTC subway is 2 minutes away).
cons:
Unfortunately, things at UHN don't move forward as quickly as they should be, especially if you work for IT and you're used to Agile and other IT frameworks. Because of that, there is a huge delay when trying to get the internal processes to finally come to the desired solution, and yet, it's very laborious to get anything done that relies on more than one IT team. 

I'd like to mention that sometimes when simple things should be a no-brainer (i.e.: getting pieces of furniture), it could take more than months. I've seen great top-notch world-class scientists with amazing potential getting frustrated by not getting what should be a basic and quick request. 

I believe that ServiceNow is helping the company to create a more process-oriented environment, however, only for the IT processes, there is much more to be done. Without proper change management, I do see the same scenario as-is for the next upcoming years. 

Nevertheless, the core point of contact for IT-related issues is the HelpDesk team which seems to be demotivated and will not solve the issues the first time you call.

review_title: 8 Eaton South, Mental Health Inpatient unit and PICU
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Toronto, ON
pros: Front line staff were tightly knit in the shared trauma and ongoing dread of what the unit had become.
cons:
The manager was a disaster. A total micromanager. Couldn't even replace chairs that had screws sticking up out of them into your rear for the main nursing station, for months. We had to place linens on the chairs for months to block the stabbing screws (apparently after I left as I've been told when something like infection control eventually saw the issue it was resolved despite previously multiple attempts to get the manager to resolve it).

She used the cameras inappropriately to observe staff, rather than patients, and punish them based on these observations.

She wouldn't support staff who had been doing only day shifts or night shifts and tried to force them to change their schedule after years of it being accommodating to the staff's needs.

She removed all the casual staff from the roster. Refused to allow exiting staff to remain casual. Even in the face of the pandemic and chronic staffing shortages.

Refused to hire new staff for RN lines that had been empty for ages.

Refused to hire new support workers, using agency staff daily that had never been to the unit, and had no idea how the mental health unit was organized, which caused more work than help

Expect workplace violence from the patients, and zero support from the manager. Not even a follow up "how are you doing after that violent assault/ terrible experience etc.?"

I'm literally traumatized by the manager's inaction, absenteeism, inability to follow up or support the staff. 

She wouldn't even approach you with concerns, going immediately to set up meetings with HR and the union, sending a vague email intimidating you that a discussion needed to be had without telling you what the issues were.

All of the psychiatrists left within the span of a few months, shortly after I started, as well as the previous PCC and manager (ON THE SAME DAY) which I think was to do with the new medical model which allowed for less of a focus on mental health and started accepting acutely physically unwell, medically complex patients. 

The ability to provide excellent mental health nursing diminished severely as we became taskmasters just trying to get the tasks done and our heads above the water. Ever since these changes the doctors were on a 2-3 week rotation. So consistency of care was a disaster as many patients would rotate through multiple doctors as their length of stay would overlap or extend past that of the doctors. (I liked the docs though just wish they were consistent). No consideration was made for the fact the tenured mental health nurses had not been practicing their physical nursing skills for years and they were thrown to the wolves to figure it out themselves.

IIRC 34 beds. 6 of which were PICU. PICU nursing ratio was 3:1.
General side ratio would be up to 6:1 on a day shift, and 9or10:1 at night as they worked with fewer staff.

The schedule itself was also terrible, 2 weeks of days, 2 weeks of nights. Monday, Tuesday, Friday, Saturday, Sunday, Wednesday, Thursday. Repeating.

Expect constant sick calls, working short, ongoing safety issues and unresolved issues that management is aware of and ignoring. I've never been happier since leaving that place, though I do miss dearly working with my excellent front line team.

CEO and senior management were for the most part very open about organizational issues and budgetary constraints. COVID response was handled very well.

Throughout my employment term there were always talks of budget deficits and staff cuts. Multiple projects had been cut or stopped due to lack of budget and the COVID pandemic.

Mgt or those on 8 hour shifts can take a week off and be under the 36 hour punitive policy Nurses and those on 12 hour shifts take more than 3 days and they get a letter - does not matter if you have MD note

review_title: So many executives and more executive VPS each day
pros: You have an opportunity as a health care practitioner to work with amazing peers and make a difference in someone's life.
cons:
Staffing resources are inadequate and renewing or growing the front line staff is not being invested in (all the money is going to executives)
There is no work life balance and you will be told you are inefficient in eeting your workload demands rather than the patient volume is growing rapidly. without staffing ratios also expanding
Little opportunity for career mobility or mentorship
Toxic, petty managers more interested in their reputations than advocating for the needs of their staff.

review_title: Postdocs are still not recognized as employees...
pros: The research environment at UHN is cutting-edge, dynamic and collaborative. Many teaching hospitals around with lots of expertise
cons: While many postdoctoral research fellows across Canada are now recognized as university employees (including postdoctoral fellows at the University of Toronto as of September 2013), those at University Health Network continue to be viewed as trainees. As such, our salary ($40,000/year/no benefits) is treated as a fellowship and is not currently insurable i.e. we are not allowed to contribute to the employment insurance (EI) program and therefore cannot claim EI for sick leave, maternity leave and such... Yet we still have to pay taxes... Overall, this makes for a rather unsecure work environment that is not rewarding at all given all the hours we pour into the research.

review_title: I would not recommend to my friends at all
pros: UHN is a large organization with several teaching hospitals and research facilities. You can get an easy access to research technologies and equipment.
cons:
Postdoctoral fellow here is a slave with zero benefit. Our status is not an official employee, yet we are considered to be an employee (not a trainee) when only it comes to tax. 
PIs are only thinking about their fame and careers, and postdoctoral fellows are just " tools" to produce scientific results. We are not appreciated or evaluated properly for the fact that we are the ones who contribute majority of great science. PI and doctors are the only ones who are protected by this organization.

pros: It's great being part of a network of some of the best medical researchers and healthcare providers in the world. The network and ties to the University give you amazing access to resources, people, and information. And, it goes without saying, working in healthcare makes you feel like what you do really is making a difference to people.
cons: It can feel rather impersonal, especially on the research side. The Network is made up of so many independent research units and teams that it's easy to get lost in the shuffle and feel underappreciated. It's also frustrating working within the many limitations of 'the system', but of course, that's the nature of healthcare.

review_title: Very difficult and at times toxic atmosphere.  Serious problem with the culture of the institution.
pros: Good benefits, PMH is well supported by the community, great potential.
cons: Political, bureaucratic and overly corporate culture.  To much of a focus on institutional risk management over patient-centric care.  Senior management out of touch.  Many managers/leaders who have lost their humanity and given in to ego fulfillment and selfish advancement.  General morale is poor.

pros: Most positions comes with a fantastic pension, both in terms of the amount that the company contributes and the fund managers at the pension.  Company has relatively low employee turnover rate in most departments.
cons: Being on the largest health care providers in the country, there are bound to be many layers of management.  This slows down the time required to actually make things happen. Career advancement opportunities not as readily available as other industries.  Compensation slightly below market.

cons: Very bottom heavy PMO department and very difficult to move up; poor work-life balance; not enough people for the projects the PMO takes on (too few resources, but you still have to deliver); HR strategy gets shelved because of other priorities.

review_title: Great place to work with potential for very rewarding experiences.

cons: Like any large organization (10,000+), processes and policies can get in the way and slow things down. And like many other hospitals in Ontario, salary freezes can be discouraging for career growth and overall satisfaction. This issue is not unique as all public sector jobs in Ontario are facing the same challenge.
